name: treatment of waste, electrical and electronic cables, open burning | waste, electrical and electronic cables | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21364/documentation

This dataset represents the activity of waste disposal of 'waste, electrical and electronic cables' in uncontrolled, open burning. Recommended use of this dataset: The process takes place in an informal recycling site in the capital of Ghana, Accra. Copper recovery is a source of income for the informal recyclers and hence is the major motive behind this process. This dataset models emissions from open burning of electrical and electronic cables. Any geographical and temporal distinctions and climate situation are irrelevant for this UPR-LCI. Inventoried waste contains 62% Copper in waste cables; 38% wire insulation for copper cables; . Waste composition (wet, in ppm): upper heating value 10.54 MJ/kg; lower heating value 10.46 MJ/kg; H2O 978.12; O 8817.5; H 28360; C 208470; S 316.9; N 420.08; P n.a.; B n.a.; Cl 119920; Br 19.74; F 5.612; I n.a.; Ag n.a.; As 0.72096; Ba 77.987; Cd 4.7186; Co 8.5942; Cr 12.338; Cu 629510; Hg 0.23135; Mn 24.801; Mo n.a.; Ni 5.588; Pb 6.7106; Sb 12.612; Se 0.79685; Sn 99.065; V 338.07; Zn 55.608; Be 0.18973; Sc n.a.; Sr 33.581; Ti 379.45; Tl 0.15178; W n.a.; Si n.a.; Fe 1172; Ca 306.97; Al 75.89; K n.a.; Mg 11.369; Na 556.09; . Share of metals in waste not oxidised and bulk-recyclable (exclude very small or thin parts) copper: 99.9%. Recycling rates for metallic iron = 95% for metallic aluminium = 0% for metallic copper = 95% . From the burn residues 0.598kg copper, are separated and recycled. A mass of 0.106kg residues are left on ground. ;The composition of waste electrical and electronic cables (62% copper and 38% "wire insulation for copper cables") is documented in the respective dataset reference. The fraction "wire insulation for copper cables" is composed by 66.3% PVC, 31.2% PE and Cu 2.5%. Reference: Doka G. (2009) Life Cycle Inventories of Waste Treatment Services. ecoinvent report;No. 13. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, St. Gallen;Reference: Amoyaw-Osei, Y & Agyekum, O.O. & Pwamang, John & Thiébaud (-Müller), Esther & Fasko, R & Schluep, Mathias. (2011). Ghana e-waste country assessment. SBC e-waste Africa project.;;;Picture source: Oeko-Institut

The activity starts with the waste being available at the location (gate) of the uncontrolled disposal. Collection and transportation of the waste to the uncontrolled disposal location is not included.


The activity ends with the waste being disposed, in an uncontrolled manner and waste-specific emissions from open burning are released to the environment (air and soil).
category: E:Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities/38:Waste collection, treatment and disposal activities; materials recovery/382:Waste treatment and disposal/3821:Treatment and disposal of non-hazardous waste

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This dataset represents a generic open burning without any temporal distinction.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Modelling parameters representing a generic open burning process, not geographical specific.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This is an inventory for open burning of solid waste. Informal or uncontrolled burning. No flue gas treatment. Suitable for informal recycling (e.g. burning of e-waste). Based on Municipal waste incineration without any pollution control. Residues (minus any actually recycled metals) are left on site. Assumption of share of thermal NOx to total NOx in average waste burning process is 30%. Contribution from thermal NOx is 810mg per kg waste. Recycling rates for metallic iron = 95% for metallic aluminium = 0% for metallic copper = 95% .
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
The waste composition was derived from literature. All information are found in the general comment. The UPR-LCI is created with a model for waste-specific life cycle inventories of open burning of waste.

Reference for the model: 
Doka G. (2017) A model for waste-specific life cycle inventories of open burning of waste. Doka Life Cycle
Assessments, Zurich, Switzerland. Available at http://www.doka.ch/publications.htm
